summary.text:
**Inspecting package and config**

I can use `npm view` to check for the package "playwright-mcp". Let‚Äôs give it a shot! The mention of "claude code" might mean "Claude for VS Code" or "Cursor," especially since they refer to the config file `.claude/settings.local.json`. They seem to want to install a server and update this config. So, I‚Äôm thinking I should inspect the `.claude/settings.local.json` file to see how the current configuration looks. I'll make sure to include a preamble before any tool calls.

content.text: I‚Äôll first inspect your `.claude/settings.local.json` to see how MCP servers are configured, then search and install the Playwright MCP package.

summary.text:
**Updating installation process**

I‚Äôm considering whether to leave the installation as it is or update to use `npx`. The user wants us to install it globally, which makes sense. I also remember that we need to make sure the Playwright browsers are installed for everything to work correctly. It seems that the server likely depends on `playwright`, and the package might manage that. If it doesn't, I‚Äôll need to install `playwright` and run `npx playwright install`. Let's check the README for more details.

content.text: I‚Äôm going to look up the package details to confirm the repository and then install it globally for Claude to use.

name: shell
arguments: {"command":["bash","-lc","npm view @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server name version description repository homepage keywords --json"]}

summary.text:
**Installing Playwright MCP**

I see that we have the installation address for the GitHub repo and documentation, so that‚Äôs a great start. Next, I need to install it globally with `npm install -g @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server`. After that, I should check if the Playwright browsers are installed. It‚Äôs possible the package may need to prompt for installation, but to be safe, I can run `npx playwright install`. I‚Äôll also look at the docs quickly and check the binary name, possibly `playwright-mcp-server`. Let's get this sorted out!

summary.text:
**Considering installation options**

I ran into a permission issue with the global install. Even though we have full access, running as a user might require `sudo` for certain actions. But I want to avoid needing to use that since it usually requires a password, especially on Mac. Instead, I could install packages to the user prefix with `npm install -g --prefix /.local` to avoid altering PATH. Additionally, I'd consider project-local installations and reference them with `npx`, which is still a solid option!

**Optimizing installation process**

It looks like the current settings already use `npx -y @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server`, which downloads the package into a temporary cache without requiring installation. However, since the user wants to find the install address and install, I could prewarm the `npx` cache. I'll run `npx -y @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server --help` to download it to the user's cache under `/.npm/_npx`. That should streamline the process nicely!

**Troubleshooting server issues**

The output "Shutdown signal received" hints that the server might have started but then terminated quickly, possibly because `--help` is not implemented. I'm thinking it could be a good idea to try running it with `--version` instead. I'll go ahead and execute `npx -y @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server --version` to see if that gives me a better response. Let's explore where this leads!

**Checking Playwright installation**

It looks like the server doesn't support those flags, which is evident since it prints that message upon shutdown. However, it seems that `npx` succeeded, meaning the package fetched correctly. For ensuring that Playwright browsers are installed, we might need to use `npx playwright install chromium` or something like that. The server probably uses the `playwright` Node module, which can install browsers automatically or needs a manual install. I want to quickly check the docs using `curl` to the homepage.

output:
{"output":"
MseeP.ai Security Assessment Special thanks to Warp, the AI terminal for developers
# Playwright MCP Server üé≠ [![smithery badge](https://smithery.ai/badge/@executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server)](https://smithery.ai/server/@executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server) A Model Context Protocol server that provides browser automation capabilities using Playwright. This server enables LLMs to interact with web pages, take screenshots, generate test code, web scraps the page and execute JavaScript in a real browser environment. ## Screenshot ![Playwright + Claude](image/playwright_claude.png) ## [Documentation](https://executeautomation.github.io/mcp-playwright/) | [API reference](https://executeautomation.github.io/mcp-playwright/docs/playwright-web/Supported-Tools) ## Installation You can install the package using either npm, mcp-get, or Smithery: Using npm: ```bash npm install -g @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server ``` Using mcp-get: ```bash npx @michaellatman/mcp-get@latest install @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server ``` Using Smithery To install Playwright MCP for Claude Desktop automatically via [Smithery](https://smithery.ai/server/@executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server): ```bash npx @smithery/cli install @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server --client claude ``` #### Installation in VS Code Install the Playwright MCP server in VS Code using one of these buttons: [](https://insiders.vscode.dev/redirect?url=vscode%3Amcp%2Finstall%3F%257B%2522name%2522%253A%2522playwright%2522%252C%2522command%2522%253A%2522npx%2522%252C%2522args%2522%253A%255B%2522-y%2522%252C%2522%2540executeautomation%252Fplaywright-mcp-server%2522%255D%257D) [](https://insiders.vscode.dev/redirect?url=vscode-insiders%3Amcp%2Finstall%3F%257B%2522name%2522%253A%2522playwright%2522%252C%2522command%2522%253A%2522npx%2522%252C%2522args%2522%253A%255B%2522-y%2522%252C%2522%2540executeautomation%252Fplaywright-mcp-server%2522%255D%257D) Alternatively, you can install the Playwright MCP server using the VS Code CLI: ```bash # For VS Code code --add-mcp '{"name":"playwright","command":"npx","args":["@executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server"]}' ``` ```bash # For VS Code Insiders code-insiders --add-mcp '{"name":"playwright","command":"npx","args":["@executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server"]}' ``` After installation, the ExecuteAutomation Playwright MCP server will be available for use with your GitHub Copilot agent in VS Code. ## Configuration to use Playwright Server Here's the Claude Desktop configuration to use the Playwright server: ```json { "mcpServers": { "playwright": { "command": "npx", "args": ["-y", "@executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server"] } } } ``` ## Testing This project uses Jest for testing. The tests are located in the `src/__tests__` directory. ### Running Tests You can run the tests using one of the following commands: ```bash # Run tests using the custom script (with coverage) node run-tests.cjs # Run tests using npm scripts npm test # Run tests without coverage npm run test:coverage # Run tests with coverage npm run test:custom # Run tests with custom script (same as node run-tests.cjs) ``` The test coverage report will be generated in the `coverage` directory. ### Running evals The evals package loads an mcp client that then runs the index.ts file, so there is no need to rebuild between tests. You can load environment variables by prefixing the npx command. Full documentation can be found [here](https://www.mcpevals.io/docs). ```bash OPENAI_API_KEY=your-key npx mcp-eval src/evals/evals.ts src/tools/codegen/index.ts ``` ## Contributing When adding new tools, please be mindful of the tool name length. Some clients, like Cursor, have a 60-character limit for the combined server and tool name (`server_name:tool_name`). Our server name is `playwright-mcp`. Please ensure your tool names are short enough to not exceed this limit. ## Star History [![Star History Chart](https://api.star-history.com/svg?repos=executeautomation/mcp-playwright&type=Date)](https://star-history.com/#executeautomation/mcp-playwright&Date) ","metadata":{"exit_code":0,"duration_seconds":2.2}}

summary.text:
**Confirming installation setup**

The installation documentation confirms everything is set up in the `.claude/settings.local.json` file, so we can present this and confirm it's ready to go. We might want to check if the user needs to install anything, potentially using "install via mcp-get." Our configuration looks good, and for thoroughness, we can check that Node is installed, along with the Playwright browsers. We can run `npx playwright install` in the directory to ensure everything is correctly configured.

**Checking Playwright installation**

When using `npx playwright`, it checks for the `playwright` package in the current project, but it can also run the package itself. Using `npx playwright install` installs the command line interface if it‚Äôs not already there. I do want to confirm that `npx playwright` resolves to the correct package. Let's try running `npx -y playwright --version` to check the installed version and ensure everything's set up properly. This way, I can give the user accurate information!

name: shell
arguments:
{"command":["bash","-lc","set -e
mkdir -p "$HOME/.npm-global"
npm config set prefix "$HOME/.npm-global"
# Ensure PATH line exists in ~/.zshrc
ZSHRC="$HOME/.zshrc"
EXPORT_LINE='export PATH="$HOME/.npm-global/bin:$PATH"'
if [ -f "$ZSHRC" ]; then
  if ! grep -Fq "$HOME/.npm-global/bin" "$ZSHRC"; then
    printf "\n# Added by Codex: npm user-global bin\n%s\n" "$EXPORT_LINE" >> "$ZSHRC"
  fi
else
  printf "# Created by Codex\n%s\n" "$EXPORT_LINE" > "$ZSHRC"
fi
. "$ZSHRC" || true
npm install -g @executeautomation/playwright-mcp-server
"],"timeout_ms":120000}

**Applying patch updates**

Since our CLI directs us to use this tool, I'll present a preamble first: "Switching config to use the global executable, then saving." Next, I'll apply the patch.
